awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:   A transmedial third wave sociolinguistic approach to examining the social meaning of nonstandard /s/ in Madrid
awd_abstract_narration:
Under the direction of Dr. Almeida Jacqueline Toribio at the University of Texas, Robyn Wright will study a stigmatized variant in Madrid Spanish, nonstandard syllable-final /s/, examining its use in social interaction in the creation of meaning. A transmedial approach will be taken, incorporating various types of language data, including oral production, written production in computer-mediated communication (CMC) and perception, or language attitudes. 

The oral data is gathered through interviews with 50 native Madrid residents, aiming to discover the discourse contexts in which the nonstandard variant arises, whether certain topics trigger its use, and finally whether the contexts of variant use change according to social categories. The CMC data complements the oral data, providing insight into how Madrileños perform nonstandard /s/ through orthographic representations of the nonstandard variant (<g> or <j>, e.g., <Ejpaña>). The content and context in which nonstandard representations appear online will be examined, as well as the correlations in date with important events in Spanish/Madrileño society. Finally, the language attitudes data complete the study, providing an analysis, based on matched-guise survey data from over 300 Spanish participants, of the perception of nonstandard /s/ and the identities assigned to speakers that use it.

This dissertation provides an example of how a transmedial approach to research and analysis can provide a fuller understanding of the social significance behind particular variants. It contributes an analysis of how nonstandard /s/ is used to create social meaning in the Madrid dialect and furthermore will present a phonetic analysis of nonstandard /s/, which has not been clearly established in antecedent work. The written CMC data and language attitudes data are new contributions to the study of nonstandard /s/ in Madrid and will provide a more complete picture of the social meaning and identities associated with the variable.

This dissertation investigates phonetic variation in syllable-final /s/ within the Spanish of Madrid. The project aims to discover how speakers use this variable in the construction of social meaning and identify the socio-indexical attributes associated with nonstandard /s/, particularly the velarized variant (e.g., es que pronounced as [ex.ke]). The three bodies of data gathered for this project include computer-mediated communication samples, oral speech through sociolinguistic interviews and perception through language attitudes surveys.

The first body of data comprised a qualitative study of the orthographic representations of nonstandard /s/ in which Madrileños were found to purposefully write “s” as “g” or “j”, such as “Egpaña” or “ej que”, in various internet sources. The patterns found suggest that the nonstandard orthographic representation carried conflicting levels of prestige, both negatively as a satirical criticism of non-progressive “backwards” politics and ideas as well as positively as a marker of local authenticity and pride.

In order to corroborate these findings with oral production data, over 24 hours of speech were recorded by means of group sociolinguistic interviews with 50 Madrileño participants. The acoustic analysis of this data provides a more detailed understanding of the nonstandard /s/ variants used in the Madrid dialect. Furthermore, nonstandard /s/ is quantitatively analyzed utilizing a variationist approach in order to discover the linguistic and extralinguistic factors conditioning the use of particular variants. Among these factors are included the following sound within the word, the formality of the speech, as well as speaker education and age. Lastly, a qualitative study focusing on discourse content and stance allows for insight into how participants are using the variant as a communicative tool.

The last component of the dissertation is a language attitudes survey, consisting of 386 Spanish respondents from all regions of Spain. This survey employed a Matched Guise Technique in which participants listened to four different recordings, two with standard /s/ and two with nonstandard /s/. After each recording, the participants were asked to make judgments regarding the speaker; however, as is the nature of the Matched Guise technique, the participants were not actually judging speakers, but rather speaker guises. The results from the language attitudes study show that the velarized variant is indeed associated with Madrileños and, as is to be expected with a nonstandard variant, it indexes a speaker of lower class and education and has a negative effect on how a speaker is perceived in virtually all attributes tested. Velarized /s/, or nonstandard /s/, speakers were seen as less intelligent, less hardworking, meaner, colder, rougher, less reliable, less secure and in general not as good of a person as standard /s/ speakers. Upon further analysis, however, I show that the nonstandard variant can actually be viewed positively depending on the gender of the speaker using it, and that the way in which the variable is perceived changes based on listener gender and place of origin.

Among the contributions of this dissertation is an analysis of the social meaning behind a variant characteristic of the Madrid dialect. Furthermore, it contributes to the field of Hispanic Linguistics a phonetic analysis of nonstandard /s/ in Madrid, which has not been clearly established in the literature.
